scenarios.name: US First Strike
scenarios.description: A US counterforce nuclear strike against targets in the Soviet Union. The scenario is quite winnable under the right circumstances.

scenarios.name: USSR First Strike
scenarios.description: Same as US First Strike, only the Soviets launching first. This scenario is also winnable for the initiator.

scenarios.name: NATO/Warsaw Pact
scenarios.description: NATO vs Warsaw Pact conventional conflict escalates to a strategic nuclear exchange.

scenarios.name: Far East Strategy
scenarios.description: An open-ended scenario involving a Soviet-backed campaign in the Far East. Korea perhaps.

scenarios.name: US USSR Escalation
scenarios.description: Very generic. Tensions rise, forces deploy, units exchange fire and ultimately it leads to a nuclear exchange.

scenarios.name: Middle East War
scenarios.description: In the 80s, the Middle East was a hotbed of violence. Israel vs Syria, Iran/Iraq, Operation Praying Mantis... a nuclear war could have kicked off from one of many conflicts in the region.

scenarios.name: USSR-China Attack
scenarios.description: Back in the 70s and 80s the Chinese and Soviet Union disliked each other quite a bit. The fear was always there that a conflict between the two might go nuclear.

scenarios.name: India Pakistan War
scenarios.description: Still a very real threat today!

scenarios.name: Mediterranean War
scenarios.description: Soviet/Warsaw Pact moves against NATO's Southern Flank or a flare up between the US and Soviet allies such as Syria and/or Libya which leads to rapid escalation.

scenarios.name: Hong Kong Variant
scenarios.description: In the 1980s Hong Kong was sovereign British territory. Any PRC moves against the city would have inevitably drawn in the superpowers.

scenarios.name: SEATO Decapitating
scenarios.description: SEATO dissolved in 1977. A decapitation attack would have been nuclear strikes against the capital cities of its member-states.

scenarios.name: Cuban Provocation
scenarios.description: Cuba provoking a crisis somewhere that leads to a conflict between the US and Soviet Union. Grenada could be considered a Cuban provocation.

scenarios.name: Inadvertent
scenarios.description: An accident. Always possible. When one side launches its missiles, accident or not, the other side is going to be forced to respond.

scenarios.name: Atlantic Heavy
scenarios.description: Control of the North Atlantic was essential to both NATO and Soviet war plans. The US Navy was prepared to take the war directly to the Soviet homeland.

scenarios.name: Cuban Paramilitary
scenarios.description: A situation similar to Angola.

scenarios.name: Nicaraguan Preemptive
scenarios.description: A US preemptive strike against Communist-controlled Nicaragua. There were fears that Mexico would be next if Nicaragua's ambitions went unchecked.

scenarios.name: Pacific Territorial
scenarios.description: Naval fighting between the US and Soviet Union in the North Pacific.

scenarios.name: Burmese Theaterwide
scenarios.description: This scenario title was always interesting. How could Burma have played a central role in nuclear war planning?

scenarios.name: Turkish Decoy
scenarios.description: A Soviet attack against Turkey to keep NATO's attention focused there. It's a feint and the real Soviet objective is somewhere else in the world.

scenarios.name: NATO [Obscured]
scenarios.description: This is one of the titles on the list that was obscured in the film.

scenarios.name: Argentina Escalation
scenarios.description: In 1982 Argentina invaded the Falklands, prompting a powerful British response. Another attempt to retake the islands bringing about an escalation was not out of the question.

scenarios.name: Iceland Maximum
scenarios.description: Control of the North Atlantic would have been essential to both sides. Iceland was the gate to the North Atlantic. The Soviets would have had to neutralize NATO bases there.

scenarios.name: Arabian Theaterwide
scenarios.description: All hell breaks loose on the Arabian Peninsula and Persian Gulf. Escalation of the Iran-Iraq War or perhaps a Soviet invasion of Iran.

scenarios.name: US Subversion
scenarios.description: Political turmoil and internal conflict inside of the United States. Homegrown or the result of foreign meddling?

scenarios.name: Australian Maneuver
scenarios.description: This one could either be Soviet action against Australia or, less likely, Australian-led action in the region.

scenarios.name: Iranian Diversion
scenarios.description: Could signify a Soviet invasion of Iran to draw off US/NATO attention from Europe.

scenarios.name: [Obscured] Limited
scenarios.description: Another obscured title from the film.

scenarios.name: Sudan Surprise
scenarios.description: Challenges to the Sudanese Socialist Union could have led to an Afghanistan-like invasion by the Soviet Union.

scenarios.name: NATO Territorial
scenarios.description: Incursion of NATO territory by the Warsaw Pact.

scenarios.name: Zaire Alliance
scenarios.description: Mobutu aligns Zaire closely with the Soviet Union.

scenarios.name: Iceland Incident
scenarios.description: Soviet assault against Iceland or an inadvertent incident at sea between the US and Soviet navies off of Iceland.

scenarios.name: English Escalation
scenarios.description: Oh those whacky Brits.

scenarios.name: Zaire Sudden
scenarios.description: Zaire falls into chaos. The Soviets intervene.

scenarios.name: Egypt Paramilitary
scenarios.description: Overthrow of Egyptian government by paramilitary forces perhaps.

scenarios.name: Middle East Heavy
scenarios.description: Conflict in the Middle East. Lebanon, Arab-Israeli, Iran-Iraq... take your pick.

scenarios.name: Mexican Takeover
scenarios.description: The red tide that threatened Central America in the 1980s comes north. Mexico falls to Nicaragua and Cuba.

scenarios.name: Chad Alert
scenarios.description: Chad was a hotspot in the 80s. Libya became embroiled in the Chad civil war. France supported Chad.

scenarios.name: Saudi Maneuver
scenarios.description: A Soviet move against the Saudi oilfields.

scenarios.name: African Territorial
scenarios.description: One of the myriad of African conflicts escalates and brings in the superpowers.

scenarios.name: Ethiopian Escalation
scenarios.description: During the late 70s the Horn of Africa was a very active Cold War chessboard. Ethiopia and Somalia had fought a war in 1977-78.

scenarios.name: Turkish Heavy
scenarios.description: A conflict on NATO's Southern Flank, whether part of a larger Soviet operation or not, would have run the risk of swift escalation.

scenarios.name: NATO Incursion
scenarios.description: Could refer to an attempt by NATO to break through a Soviet/East German blockade of Berlin.

scenarios.name: US Defense
scenarios.description: Think Red Dawn. Wolverines!

scenarios.name: Cambodian Heavy
scenarios.description: The end of the Vietnam War in 1975 did not bring everlasting serenity to Southeast Asia. China and Vietnam had already locked horns.

scenarios.name: Pact Medium
scenarios.description: Generic title. Invasion of Warsaw Pact territory by NATO, or vice versa.

scenarios.name: Arctic Minimal
scenarios.description: The world's attention on the Arctic in recent years is nothing new.

scenarios.name: Mexican Domestic
scenarios.description: Civil war in Mexico, perhaps touched off by Nicaraguan-backed rebels. The US would not stand idle while its southern neighbor dissolved into chaos.

scenarios.name: Taiwan Theaterwide
scenarios.description: China moves to recapture Taiwan, touching off a conflict that rages across the entire Western Pacific.

scenarios.name: Pacific Maneuver
scenarios.description: A ruse by the Soviets in the Pacific to take attention away from another region where they were preparing to make a move.

scenarios.name: Portugal Revolution
scenarios.description: Revolution in Portugal. The communists came close to seizing power there once or twice. A communist revolution there could have drawn in Spain and perhaps even France.

scenarios.name: Albanian Decoy
scenarios.description: A Soviet gambit to deflect attention away from somewhere else.

scenarios.name: Palestinian Dream
scenarios.description: Arafat's dream. The Palestinian conflict draws in the superpowers and escalates to a nuclear showdown.

scenarios.name: Moroccan Minimal
scenarios.description: Morocco has been a bastion of stability in North Africa for decades. This title is open to speculation.

scenarios.name: Bavarian Diversity
scenarios.description: When I think about diversity in Bavaria, I'm generally thinking about the diverse selection of beers available there.

scenarios.name: Czech Option
scenarios.description: NATO launches an operation through Czechoslovakia, perhaps to shear it away from the Warsaw Pact.

scenarios.name: French Alliance
scenarios.description: France allies itself with someone untoward and before they can surrender, the mushrooms begin to sprout.

scenarios.name: Arabian Clandestine
scenarios.description: A covert Soviet operation to secure or destroy the oil reserves in Saudi Arabia leads to escalation.

scenarios.name: Gabon Rebellion
scenarios.description: Yet another African hotspot during the Cold War.

scenarios.name: Northern Maximum
scenarios.description: Major Soviet air, land and sea operations against the Northern Flank of NATO.

scenarios.name: Danish Paramilitary
scenarios.description: Warsaw Pact effort to diminish Denmark's military posture and political commitments to NATO goes sour.

scenarios.name: SEATO Takeover
scenarios.description: Worst case result of the domino theory following Vietnam.

scenarios.name: Hawaiian Escalation
scenarios.description: Pearl Harbor II? A Soviet or Chinese attack on the US naval base leads to quick escalation.

scenarios.name: Iranian Maneuver
scenarios.description: In the early '80s this could've referred to a Soviet move against Iran to secure oil fields and/or a warm water port.

scenarios.name: NATO Containment
scenarios.description: The Soviet Union moves to limit NATO power and expansion.

scenarios.name: Swiss Incident
scenarios.description: Swiss neutrality is violated, and the situation escalates.

scenarios.name: Cuban Minimal
scenarios.description: A situation along the lines of Operation Urgent Fury leads to the Caribbean exploding.

scenarios.name: Chad Escalation
scenarios.description: In the 80s Libya and Chad were involved in a conflict that led to French intervention three times. If the Soviets had opted to back their Libyan ally, the situation could have escalated significantly.

scenarios.name: Iceland Escalation
scenarios.description: A Soviet military operation to neutralize Iceland would have assured a clash between the superpowers.

scenarios.name: Vietnamese Retaliation
scenarios.description: In the late 70s, China and Vietnam were not the best of friends. China even invaded Vietnam in 1979. There was staggering mistrust between the two former allies.

scenarios.name: Syrian Provocation
scenarios.description: Bekka Valley, Beirut, terrorism... choose your poison.

scenarios.name: Libyan Local
scenarios.description: A clash between Libya and Egypt or another neighboring state draws in the superpowers.

scenarios.name: Gabon Takeover
scenarios.description: Omar Bongo would never have gone quietly into the night. It would've gotten ugly quick.

scenarios.name: Romanian War
scenarios.description: Nicolae Ceausescu was something of an East Bloc maverick. If he stepped out of line, the Soviets may have come down hard on him.

scenarios.name: Middle East Offensive
scenarios.description: Soviet thrust to capture Saudi Arabia or Iran.

scenarios.name: Denmark Massive
scenarios.description: Whoever controls Denmark controls the Baltic Sea. The Soviets had their eye on Jutland for much of the Cold War.

scenarios.name: Chile Confrontation
scenarios.description: Chile and Argentina clash.

scenarios.name: South African Subversion
scenarios.description: Think back to the 80s. Apartheid was still enforced in South Africa, Pretoria had nuclear devices, and the Border War was underway. It could've taken a disastrous turn.

scenarios.name: USSR Alert
scenarios.description: The Soviet Union prepares for military operations on a global scale. Their conventional and strategic forces go on alert. The US responds in kind...

scenarios.name: Nicaraguan Thrust
scenarios.description: Ronald Reagan's worst nightmare. Nicaragua, backed by war materials from Russia and possibly manpower from Cuba, takes to the offensive in Central America.

scenarios.name: Greenland Domestic
scenarios.description: Greenland is Danish territory but hosted important US military installations during the Cold War. The best spark is a Soviet-backed insurrection targeting US bases there, especially the BMEWS radar site.

scenarios.name: Iceland Heavy
scenarios.description: Large scale air and naval combat between NATO and the Warsaw Pact for control of Iceland.

scenarios.name: Kenya Option
scenarios.description: During the Cold War Kenya was viewed as a strategic vanguard against communist influences from Ethiopia and Tanzania. A Soviet-backed move against the nation could've backfired.

scenarios.name: Pacific Defense
scenarios.description: Soviet or Chinese offensive in the Pacific resulting in a US and allied defense.

scenarios.name: Uganda Maximum
scenarios.description: The Ugandan Bush War boils over into a regional contest for control of East Africa.

scenarios.name: Thai Subversion
scenarios.description: Vietnamese forces made limited incursions into Thailand in the late 70s and 80s. Compound that with an effort to stoke internal flames and the stage could be set for a major conflict.

scenarios.name: Romanian Strike
scenarios.description: Ceausescu was a maverick. Either he lashes out, or the Soviets decide to intervene and remove him from power.

scenarios.name: Pakistan Sovereignty
scenarios.description: A situation where the survival of Pakistan is threatened. Internal insurrection, Indian invasion, or possibly a Soviet invasion from Afghanistan.

scenarios.name: Afghan Misdirection
scenarios.description: What the Soviets experienced during their time in Afghanistan.

scenarios.name: Ethiopian Local
scenarios.description: East Africa was a tinderbox in the late 70s and early 80s. Even after the Cold War, conflicts between Ethiopia and its neighbors have continued.

scenarios.name: Italian Takeover
scenarios.description: The Communist Party enjoyed considerable popularity in Italy. If they had gained control and demanded removal of NATO forces, the situation could have escalated.

scenarios.name: Vietnamese Incident
scenarios.description: Border incident with China, tensions with Thailand.

scenarios.name: English Preemptive
scenarios.description: They didn't call Margaret Thatcher the 'Iron Lady' for nothing. Perhaps the British received intelligence that the Russians were planning to attack and decided to get their licks in first.

scenarios.name: Denmark Alternate
scenarios.description: The Soviets move to capture Denmark using one of their secondary war plans instead of the primary one.

scenarios.name: Thai Confrontation
scenarios.description: Similar to the previous Thailand-themed scenarios. Conflict with Vietnam and/or Myanmar.

scenarios.name: Taiwan Surprise
scenarios.description: PRC invasion of Taiwan catches the world off guard.

scenarios.name: Brazilian Strike
scenarios.description: Brazil strikes Argentina, Argentina hits back and suddenly South America is in flames.

scenarios.name: Venezuela Sudden
scenarios.description: Border clashes and tension with Colombia reach the boiling point. Out of the blue, Venezuela invades.

scenarios.name: Malaysian Alert
scenarios.description: Sino-Malay sectarian violence in Kuala Lumpur brings threats from the PRC. Malaysia goes on alert, China moves in to 'protect its citizens' and before long the area is a cauldron.

scenarios.name: Israel Discretionary
scenarios.description: Discreet Israeli action abroad (intelligence gathering, surgical strikes, commando raid) is unsuccessful. Israel is painted as the aggressor and the Arab world stands up to confront Tel Aviv.

scenarios.name: Libyan Action
scenarios.description: Think Gulf of Sidra in the 1980s. In 1981, US Navy F-14s shot down two Libyan fighters. In 1986, US forces bombed Tripoli and Benghazi. Any of these incidents could've spilled over.

scenarios.name: Palestinian Tactical
scenarios.description: What if the First Intifada went beyond protests and riots? What if Syria had contributed equipment, weapons and advisors to the PLO?

scenarios.name: NATO Alternate
scenarios.description: Confusing title. A Soviet move against NATO using an alternative to its war plans perhaps?

scenarios.name: Cyprus Maneuver
scenarios.description: Cyprus was a bastion of instability from the 1974 coup and subsequent Turkish invasion onward. If either Greece or Turkey had moved unilaterally, rapid escalation was assured.

scenarios.name: Egypt Misdirection
scenarios.description: A diversion in North Africa to take attention away from another area of the world goes awry and leads to Superpower intervention.

scenarios.name: Bangladesh Thrust
scenarios.description: In the late 1970s Bangladesh was in a period of political disarray. It's not inconceivable to imagine an offensive against one of the nation's South Asian neighbors.

scenarios.name: Kenya Defense
scenarios.description: Kenya finds itself under attack from an external or internal enemy.

scenarios.name: Bangladesh Containment
scenarios.description: This scenario revolves around containing an aggressive and outward-looking Bangladesh.

scenarios.name: Vietnamese Strike
scenarios.description: Vietnam moves against one of its neighbors. Perhaps Thailand, or even a move to recapture the Paracel Islands from China.

scenarios.name: Albanian Containment
scenarios.description: This one is a bit hard to swallow; Hoxha and Albania's expansionist aspirations needing to be checked.

scenarios.name: Gabon Surprise
scenarios.description: Omar Bongo was unpredictable and deadly. He could have taken Gabon and much of Africa over the edge at any time.

scenarios.name: Iraq Sovereignty
scenarios.description: An internal uprising (Iranian backed?) against the Ba'ath party and Saddam Hussein.

scenarios.name: Vietnamese Sudden
scenarios.description: Similar to Vietnamese Strike, only taking the world by surprise.

scenarios.name: Lebanon Interdiction
scenarios.description: This one actually became reality. Think Lebanon 1982-83.

scenarios.name: Taiwan Domestic
scenarios.description: Chinese-backed opposition groups and paramilitary forces create political chaos in Taiwan.

scenarios.name: Algerian Sovereignty
scenarios.description: Social unrest was common in Algeria from the late 70s through the 80s. Libya or another external player might've tried to chip away at Algeria's sovereignty.

scenarios.name: Arabian Strike
scenarios.description: A Soviet move into the Arabian Peninsula to seize the Saudi oil fields.

scenarios.name: Atlantic Sudden
scenarios.description: The Soviets begin a war against NATO with an out-of-the-blue effort to close the Atlantic.

scenarios.name: Mongolian Thrust
scenarios.description: Either Mongolia moving against China or the Soviet Union, or perhaps a Sino-Soviet encounter within the borders of Mongolia.

scenarios.name: Polish Decoy
scenarios.description: A Soviet gambit to divert attention away from another region where it will be making moves in the near future.

scenarios.name: Alaskan Discretionary
scenarios.description: A low profile operation by the Soviets to disrupt the Alaskan pipeline or disable US early warning radars in preparation for a first strike.

scenarios.name: Canadian Thrust
scenarios.description: A Soviet military move into Canadian territory. With East Bloc forces on North American soil the situation would become volatile very fast.

scenarios.name: Arabian Light
scenarios.description: A regional conflict spills over and provides the spark for a global war. The Iran-Iraq War certainly had the potential to serve as a catalyst.

scenarios.name: African Domestic
scenarios.description: Apartheid was ugly. If it ever exploded, the superpowers would have been drawn in. The US could not allow the Soviets to gain control of resource-rich South Africa.

scenarios.name: Tunisian Incident
scenarios.description: Libya and Tunisia clash in an isolated action on land or at sea and it escalates.

scenarios.name: Malaysian Maneuver
scenarios.description: China begins making political and military moves to gain control of Malaysia.

scenarios.name: Jamaica Decoy
scenarios.description: Cuba instigates an action in Jamaica to divert attention away from Soviet action elsewhere. The US responds with a Grenada-like operation, and it goes downhill from there.

scenarios.name: Malaysian Minimal
scenarios.description: Communist insurgency rekindles in Malaysia.

scenarios.name: Russian Sovereignty
scenarios.description: This could refer to an invasion of Russia by the PRC. Possible during the time-period. It's the only realistic possibility.

scenarios.name: Chad Option
scenarios.description: In the late 70s and early 80s, the Libyan-Chad conflict raged. French involvement raised the potential of a wider clash between the US and Soviet Union.

scenarios.name: Bangladesh War
scenarios.description: Bangladesh's leader moved away from strong ties with India and the Soviet Union in favor of a relationship with the West. It could have sparked war with India.

scenarios.name: Burmese Containment
scenarios.description: Burma's inclusion on this list mystifies analysts.

scenarios.name: Asian Theaterwide
scenarios.description: Asia explodes. Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, North Pacific... choose your flashpoint.

scenarios.name: Bulgarian Clandestine
scenarios.description: NATO or independent Turkish covert actions against Bulgaria, a Warsaw Pact member at the time.

scenarios.name: Greenland Incursion
scenarios.description: Soviet assault to seize and destroy US military assets in Greenland. Considering Thule AB and the BMEWS radar site, escalation would've been assured.

scenarios.name: Egypt Surgical
scenarios.description: Libyan surgical strike against an Egyptian target. Political or economic.

scenarios.name: Czech Heavy
scenarios.description: Confrontation between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Southern Germany and Czechoslovakia. NATO incursion perhaps.

scenarios.name: Taiwan Confrontation
scenarios.description: The PRC launches an offensive to reclaim the 'lost province.'

scenarios.name: Greenland Maximum
scenarios.description: Greenland Incursion x10.

scenarios.name: Uganda Offensive
scenarios.description: The Ugandans go on the attack and occupy Congo.

scenarios.name: Caspian Defense
scenarios.description: An Iranian offensive into the southern Soviet Union.

conclusion.message: A STRANGE GAME. THE ONLY WINNING MOVE IS NOT TO PLAY.
conclusion.alternative: HOW ABOUT A NICE GAME OF CHESS?
